title: Extremity Soft Tissue Sarcoma
diagnosis_topic: Extremity Soft Tissue Sarcoma – Diagnosis, Staging, and Surgical Management
setup_script: “A 52-year-old woman presents with a painless enlarging mass in her left thigh that she first noticed 3 months ago. It has grown steadily and now measures about 7 cm by her report. On exam, there is a firm, deep, non-mobile mass in the anterior thigh. There is no overlying skin change. Distal neurovascular exam is normal. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: - “MRI of the thigh shows a 7.5 cm deep intramuscular mass abutting but not encasing the femur. No bone involvement is seen. What is your next step?”
- “Excisional biopsy is performed through a transverse incision. Final pathology: high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma. The margins are positive. What are the implications of this?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends core needle biopsy
dynamic_flow.reply: - “Core needle biopsy shows a high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma. What is your management plan?”
- “CT chest shows no evidence of metastatic disease. What surgical options would you consider?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident suggests wide local excision with appropriate margins
dynamic_flow.reply: - “You perform wide local excision with negative margins. How do you manage the surgical bed postoperatively?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to mention radiation therapy
dynamic_flow.reply: - “Given a 7.5 cm high-grade sarcoma resected with negative margins, what is the role of adjuvant therapy?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident mentions preoperative vs postoperative radiation
dynamic_flow.reply: - “What factors influence your choice between preoperative and postoperative radiation in this setting?”
- “Amputation is generally not indicated here. What are the current principles of limb-sparing surgery in soft tissue sarcoma?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident appropriately follows multidisciplinary care
dynamic_flow.reply: - “The patient recovers well from surgery and completes postoperative radiation. How would you structure surveillance?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays staging or adjuvant planning
dynamic_flow.reply: - “The patient re-presents 18 months later with a new lung mass. How do you proceed?”
- “CT chest shows an isolated 2.5 cm lung metastasis. Would you consider surgical resection?”

critical_decision_points: Correct biopsy technique (core needle preferred, avoid poorly placed excisional biopsy)
Use of MRI for local staging
Role of CT chest for metastatic staging
Principles of wide local excision with negative margins
Multidisciplinary approach (surgical oncology, medical oncology, radiation oncology)
